keyTakeAways: The Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant has been without off-site power for four weeks, the longest blackout since the war began, forcing reliance on emergency diesel generators.
The United Nations' nuclear watchdog, the IAEA, reported that work to restore power began after the establishment of rare 'ceasefire zones' allowing repairs to proceed.
Both Ukraine and Russia have accused each other of causing the power outage: Ukraine claims Russia intentionally cut power to test reconnection, while Russia blames Ukrainian shelling.
The Russian-controlled Zaporizhzhia plant states that Russian military forces are providing security to allow power restoration work, even in areas under active shelling.
The outage marks the tenth time since the war began that the site has lost grid connection, showing a pattern of disruption.
A previous Russian strike in Slavutych affected the former Chernobyl plant, prompting accusations from Zelensky that Moscow deliberately targeted energy infrastructure with drones.
The restoration of off-site power is vital for nuclear safety and security, as it reduces the risk of a radiation incident in Europe.
The IAEA, under Director Rafael Grossi, emphasized constructive engagement between the two sides to enable complex repair plans.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Work is underway to restore power to the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant (ZNPP) in Ukraine, following the establishment of rare 'ceasefire zones' that allow repair crews to operate. The plant has been without off-site power for four weeks—the longest blackout since the war began—forcing it to rely on emergency diesel generators. The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), led by Director Rafael Grossi, says the restoration is vital for nuclear safety and that both Ukraine and Russia engaged constructively to enable the repairs. Ukraine blames Russia for intentionally cutting power to test reconnection, while Russia attributes the outage to Ukrainian shelling and claims its military is providing security for repairs. This is the tenth time since the war began that the plant has lost grid connection. A recent Russian strike on a substation in Slavutych, which affected the former Chernobyl plant, further highlights the ongoing aggression on Ukraine’s energy infrastructure. The situation raises global concerns about nuclear safety and the risk of a radiation incident in Europe.
title: Work underway to restore power at Ukrainian nuclear plant as UN announces rare local ‘ceasefire zones’
